title: Intellectual Property
definition: Intangible property created by an individual or organisation
examples: Things you write, make or produce
purpose: Protects creators from others profiting from their hard work without consent.
Makes it easier to take legal action against anyone who steals/copies it, with an aim of making a profit.
The type of protection you can get depends on your creation
protectionDescription: When choosing to protect intellectual property, you have two main methods of doing so.

copyright.title: Copyright
copyright.description: Comes into effect automatically - protects the expression or manifestation of an idea (not the idea itself).
covers: Traditional documents like books, music articles, movies/TV
Computer software, databases, designs and multimedia
copyright.copyrightFact: Copyright (UK) normally extends beyond the author’s lifetime. However there are some exceptions:
copyright.license: Authors may license others to produce copies, often in return for royalties
copyright.softwareLimitation: Whilst software is automatically copyright, this does not prevent others from writing their own code to implement the same ideas (reverse engineering)

patents.title: Patents
patents.definition: A patent protects your invention and lets you take legal action against anyone who makes, uses, or sells your invention without your permission
patentFacts: Protects the idea behind an invention
The ideas should be original and not obvious (A new, useful and inventive step)
Patents  are published, thus benefiting public knowledge
patents.boundaries: There are clear boundaries defining what can be patented
boundaryExample: Artistic creations, mathematical models, plans, schemes or other purely mental processes cannot be patented
